abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third National Highways
            Project for India were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            lack of attention to human resource development in a period
            of rapid change in the highway sector can constrain project
            development implementation. The current shortage of
            qualified manpower is out of phase with the enormous demand
            of large infrastructure projects. The Government and
            industry need to create incentives and facilities for
            systematic training to increase the number of qualified road
            engineers, and technicians. There is also a need for
            competent environmental officers, an important career track
            not yet widely recognized in the road sector. The assignment
            of responsibility for sector studies and technical
            assistance to the implementing agency instead of the sector
            ministry can reduce the attention to a highway projects
            broader institutional and sector development aspects.
            National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) was primarily
            concerned with implementing the Ministry's policy by
            building roads. It is not clear that the organization had
            the capability to concentrate on monitoring and evaluating
            the various institutional studies. Also, policy and planning
            in the roads sector are the responsibility of the ministry
            and the studies under the project were more in line with
            this mandate than that of NHAI.

display_title.display_title:
India - Third National Highways
            Project  : India - Third National Highways Project

repnme.cdata!:
India - Third National Highway Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment discusses
            the impacts on the various environmental components, due to
            the implementation of the Third National Highways Project.
            The impacts have been identified based on secondary, and
            primary data, and, further analysis carried out for the
            project. It assesses potential impacts on climate,
            topography, and natural drainage systems, indicating no
            significant changes are expected in these areas. Conversely,
            the loss of productive soil, natural habitats, and
            bio-diversity, are major direct, and adverse long-term
            impacts, but it is proposed that acquisition of fertile land
            be minimal. Similarly, careful project design would avoid
            adversity to cultural, and archaeological sites.
            Nonetheless, during construction, it is expected that
            temporary adverse impacts will occur on human health, due to
            rising pollution levels, and vector borne diseases. An
            analysis of alternatives is provided, and, mitigating
            measures include slope stabilization through borrow pits, to
            prevent soil erosion, and sedimentation. Measures will be
            taken to minimize soil contamination due to oil spillage,
            and selected waste disposal sites will be available.
            Suitable design will minimize impacts on surface waters,
            and, other mitigating measures include noise abatement, air
            quality control, afforestation, as well as drainage, and
            sanitation infrastructure improvements.

India - Third National Highway
            Project : environmental assessment (Vol. 9) : Environmental
            management plan - Construction package 5-C

            The impacts have been identified based on secondary, and

437544.trustfund: TF026215-FINANCING OF AUSAID SECONDMENTS,TF021251-PHRD-JAPANESE CTF (USD ACCOUNT),TF036231-INDIA - NATIONAL HIGHWAYS,TF034775-INDIA - NATIONAL HIGHWAYS,TF031353-ASIA - TRANSPORTATION,TF029474-PHRD-THIRD NATIONAL HIGHWAY PROJECT,TF022511-PHRD-NATIONAL HIGHWAYS III

repnme.cdata!:
India - Third National Highway Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment discusses
            the impacts on the various environmental components, due to
            the implementation of the Third National Highways Project.
            The impacts have been identified based on secondary, and
            primary data, and, further analysis carried out for the
            project. It assesses potential impacts on climate,
            topography, and natural drainage systems, indicating no
            significant changes are expected in these areas. Conversely,
            the loss of productive soil, natural habitats, and
            bio-diversity, are major direct, and adverse long-term
            impacts, but it is proposed that acquisition of fertile land
            be minimal. Similarly, careful project design would avoid
            adversity to cultural, and archaeological sites.
            Nonetheless, during construction, it is expected that
            temporary adverse impacts will occur on human health, due to
            rising pollution levels, and vector borne diseases. An
            analysis of alternatives is provided, and, mitigating
            measures include slope stabilization through borrow pits, to
            prevent soil erosion, and sedimentation. Measures will be
            taken to minimize soil contamination due to oil spillage,
            and selected waste disposal sites will be available.
            Suitable design will minimize impacts on surface waters,
            and, other mitigating measures include noise abatement, air
            quality control, afforestation, as well as drainage, and
            sanitation infrastructure improvements.

display_title.display_title:
India - Third National Highway
            Project : environmental assessment (Vol. 3) : Environmental
            management plan - Construction package 2-C
